title: FirstFT: ‘We will hunt you down'
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

US president Joe Biden vowed to plough ahead with the evacuation of those trying to flee Afghanistan and punish the perpetrators of an attack outside Kabul's international airport that killed 13 US military personnel and dozens of Afghans.

In an attempt to appear both a sombre mourner-in-chief and a resolute leader steeling the nation for what could be a difficult final withdrawal from the Afghan capital, Biden addressed the nation yesterday from the White House.

“We will not be deterred by terrorists, we will not let them stop our mission. We will continue the evacuation,” Biden said in an emotional address. “We will not forgive. We will not forget. We will hunt you down and make you pay.”

At least 13 US military personnel died after two suicide bombs exploded near Kabul's airport yesterday. The number of Afghan civilians killed in the twin attacks has risen to at least 95, according to the Associated Press newswire.

The deadly attacks were carried out by an Isis-affiliated group and severely disrupted western efforts to wind up the evacuation of Kabul airport. The British government said today the “final stages” of its evacuation programme had begun. Germany, Spain and Canada have already completed their withdrawals. Clement Beaune, French European affairs minister, said France's evacuation operation would end “soon”.

More on Afghanistan:

  • Edward Luce: This is potentially Joe Biden's Jimmy Carter moment.

  • ‘Herat is now like a ghost city': How Afghanistan's third-largest city is adapting to Taliban rule.

  • What next for Afghanistan? Former CIA director-general David Petraeus and ex-Afghan central bank governor Ajmal Ahmady discuss the future of Afghanistan with FT journalists at a special live event.

Follow the latest coverage of Afghanistan on FT.com.

Thanks as always for reading FirstFT Americas. Have a great weekend — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. Tim Cook sells $750m of Apple stock Tim Cook sold more than $750m of Apple shares this week, after receiving the final tranche of a stock award that he was granted a decade ago when he took over the role of Apple chief executive from Steve Jobs. Filings released on Thursday show about 5m shares were sold at prices ranging between $148-$150, netting $752m for Cook.

  • Opinion: Many judge tech chief executives by their pioneering work but Apple's sales success alone is enough to vindicate Tim Cook, argues Richard Waters.

2. Peloton issues disappointing outlook Peloton shares fell as much as 14 per cent in after-hours trading after the maker of the popular video-connected exercise bikes warned that this year's profits would be hit by higher commodity prices.

3. US media deals Forbes has agreed to go public via a merger with a special purpose acquisition company that values the US business news outlet at $630m, while Axel Springer, the German publishing group backed by private equity firm KKR, struck a deal to buy Politico, in the latest eye-catching media sector deals.

4. EU to launch probe into Nvidia's $54bn Arm takeover Brussels is to launch a formal competition probe of Nvidia's planned takeover of British chip designer Arm after months of informal discussions between regulators and the US chip company.

5. Bank of America executives to bow out Tom Montag, who helped reshape Bank of America as it emerged from the 2008-09 financial crisis, will retire at the end of the year. Anne Finucane, BofA's vice-chair and one of the most senior women on Wall Street, will also step down.

Coronavirus digest

  • The US Supreme Court has invalidated the Biden administration's coronavirus pandemic-related moratorium on household evictions.

  • Wealthy countries are finalising plans to roll out Covid-19 booster programmes to counter the threat from waning vaccine immunity, against the advice of the World Health Organization.

  • New Zealand has extended lockdown measures until the end of August as Delta variant infections spread. Jacinda Ardern, prime minister, said the most severe restrictions would probably remain in place in Auckland for another two weeks.

The day ahead

Jackson Hole symposium All eyes today will be on Federal Reserve chair Jay Powell as he addresses the virtual gathering of central bankers at the Jackson Hole economic symposium for signs of when the US central bank will begin to unwind its pandemic-era stimulus programme. The Fed chair is due to speak at 10am US eastern daylight time.

  • Opinion: Powell's speech is an opportunity to give direction amid mounting uncertainty, writes Martin Sandbu in his Free Lunch newsletter. Sign up here.

Economic data The US commerce department releases consumer spending and inflation data for July. Separately, the University of Michigan is expected to report its final consumer sentiment index.

IPOs Shares in UK-based online used car seller Cazoo are expected to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange today. US rival Carvana listed in 2017 and now has a valuation of $60bn.

Purdue Pharma case A New York judge is expected to rule on a proposed bankruptcy settlement involving members of the Sackler family, who own Purdue Pharma.

Japan and Taiwan to hold talks The nations will hold their first bilateral security talks as they seek to strengthen ties to counter China.

What else we're reading

Why are there so few female economists? It seems extraordinary that academic economics is inaccessible or unattractive to women. The lack of family-friendly career paths is part of the problem, writes Tim Harford.

We should be careful which metaverse we choose to live in The great thing about the future is that you can make it up. So it is with the latest Silicon Valley infatuation: the metaverse. What this kind of internet 2.0 might look like, however, is more disturbing, writes John Thornhill.

Private equity's housing land rush leaves trail of disputes Charities and powerful investment groups are fighting in the US over affordable apartments funded by tax credits — a trend that activists said could displace families whose homes were built with billions of dollars of government subsidies.

Net tightens around Mafia fugitives Cross-border co-operation and technological advances have made life on the run more challenging for Italy's most wanted criminals. A spate of arrests this year underlined the challenges of remaining undetected in an era of pandemic travel restrictions and improved surveillance.

Young US athletes sample power and pressure of influencer culture The college sports season kicks off this weekend and for the first time stars such as football quarterback Bo Nix can earn money from sponsorship deals. But are these athletes ready for the pressures of social media-driven sports fame, asks Sara Germano. The Scoreboard newsletter has more on the business of sport. Sign up here.

Fashion

As her eponymous label turns 20, Stella McCartney opened up to the FT's fashion editor Lauren Indvik about her new role at LVMH — and why fashion needs more government regulation.
